title: Can a debt collector freeze a business account when collecting on a personal debt?
question: My husband is self-employed and is being sued by a credit card company for debt on a personal credit card. Once they get a judgement, can they freeze his business account? Would we still be able to cash his checks, just not deposit them?
answers:
Well, an ounce of prevention is worth a pound of "acocunt attachment"...so, the time to strike a deal with the credit card company is now...not after a judgement...so either hire an attorney to assist you or engage a credit card "reduction" service to handle this matter sooner rather than later...it only gets worse in time.

Is your husband a sole proprietor? If so, any account that he uses for his business is just a personal account. So under that set of circumstances, money in that account could be seized (Not just frozen) by a judgment creditor.

If your husband's business is incorporated, a judgment creditor cannot seize the corporate bank account, but it can order the seizure of the shares of stock & get to the money that way.

Sounds like you need to speak with an attorney on this matter right away.

Hope this perspective helps!

If the creditor win's a judgment, they become a a judgment creditor and can execute on their judgment by various methods, including garnishing wages, levying a bank acount (which means taking the money that's in their out), recording the judgment against real estate, placing a lien on personal property, getting an assignment order for payments he's due, etc.

If your husband has no job, he's go no wages to garnish, but the other methods remain available to the judgment creditor, and your husband's credit will be damaged by this judgment.
